monogr.author: Francis Beaumont
John Fletcher
monogr.title: Comedies and Tragedies Written by Francis Beavmont and Iohn Fletcher, Gentlemen. Never printed before, And now published by the Authours Originall Copies.

imprint.pubPlace: The Princes Armes in St. Pauls Church-yard

front.head: This cast list has been adapted from the 1679 folio edition of Beaumont and Fletcher's Fifty Comedies and Tragedies. Spelling has been regularized based on how names appear in the dialogue, and new descriptions have been supplied.

castItem.roleDesc: ship's officer in charge of equipment and the crew
French Lord looking to buy land and lordship in a new country; banished from his country
a woman aboard the ship; under the protection of Albert
leader of the female commonwealth; a firm protector of the commonwealth
daughter of Rosella; raised by only women (aka, the commonwealth)

lg.l: Alas, dear soul, ye faint.
You speak the language
Which I should use to you. Heaven knows, my weakness
Is not for what I suffer in myself,
But to imagine what you endure and to what fate
Your cruel stars reserve ye.
Do not add to my afflictions
By your tender pities. Sure, we have changed sexes:
You bear calamity with a fortitude
Would become a man; I, like a weak girl, suffer.
Oh, but your wounds,
How fearfully they gape! And every one
To me is a sepulcher sepulcher: tomb or burial place . If I loved truly—
Wise men affirm that true love can do wonders—
This, bathed in my warm tears, would soon be cured
And leave no orifice behind. Pray give me leave
To play the Surgeon and bind 'em up.
The raw air rankles rankles: festers, esp. to a degree that causes pain 'em.
Sweet, we want want: lack means.
Love can supply all wants wants: shortages.
What have ye done, sweet?
Oh sacrilege to beauty! There's no hair
Of these pure locks by which the greatest king
Would not be gladly bound and love his fetters fetters: binds, chains.
Oh, Albert! I offer this sacrifice of service

To the altar of your staid temperance and still adore it. I offer ... adore it.: This moment depicts a sacrifice of body for body with clear religious connotations playing on the word "altar" (as she alters her own body to save his).
When with a violent hand you made me yours
I cursed the doer, but now I consider:
How long I was in your power! And with what honor
You entertained me! It being seldom seen
That youth and heat of blood could e'er prescribe
Laws to itself; your goodness is the Lethe Lethe: from Greek mythology, referring to a river in Hades that causes forgetfulness
In which I drown your injuries, and now I live
Truly to serve ye. How do you, sir?
Receive you the least from my service?
If you do, I am largely recompensed recompensed: repaid.
You good angels
That are engaged when man's ability fails
To reward goodness, look upon this lady.

Though hunger grips my croaking entrails,
Albert kissing Aminta.
Yet when I kiss these rubies rubies: i.e. Aminta's lips methinks
I'm at a banquet, a refreshing banquet.
Speak, my blessèd one, art not hungry?
Indeed I could eat, to bear your company.

Blush, unkind Nature unkind Nature: This phrasing suggests Albert blames Nature (here, personified) for putting him and Aminta into this harsh environment. To bolster his point, he provides two examples of Nature's unfair treatment of them: the first one is that nature gives a "drunkard" more wine, and a "glutton" more food, though the drunkard has already drunk and has no need for more wine, and the glutton already has enough food. Thus, Albert attempts to shame Nature into providing aid to her more deserving victims, especially Aminta (a "virgin" who is "pin[ing] for hunger").,
If thou hast power or being to hear
Thyself and by such innocence accused
Must print a thousand kinds of shames upon
Thy various face, can'st thou supply a drunkard—
And with a prodigal hand reach choice of wines
'Til he cast up cast up: vomit thy blessings—or a glutton—
That robs the elements to sooth his palate
And only eats to beget appetite,
Not to be satisfied—and suffer here
A virgin—which the saints would make their guest—
To pine pine: starve or waste away for hunger? Sounding of horns.
Ha! If my sense
Deceive me not, these notes take being
From the breath of men. Confirm me, my Aminta —
Again this way the gentle wind conveys it to us—
Hear you nothing?

Yes, it seems free hunters' music free hunters' music: Albert hears music from the neighboring island. We eventually learn that the makers of this music are Portuguese women, which means that the "music" heard here might have had influences from Portugal, and possibly its colonies in the Middle East and West India. A major context for the play is European colonial dominion over other parts of the world, indicated in part by how it mimics Shakespeare's The Tempest. It is possible that some of the common music instruments possessed by the Portuguese (or instruments imagined by the playwrights to be possessed by them) could have been showcased or approximated on stage. In addition to horns, another possible sound that might have been recreated on stage is of the adufe, a square double-skinned frame drum traditionally played by women on the Iberian Peninsula. The skins are sewn together, often with seeds between them; it is held with the thumbs of both hands and the pointer of the right hand, leaving the other fingers free to hit the instrument. This instrument was introduced into Portugal (and Spain) when the Moors of North Africa conquered the Iberian Peninsula in the 8th century. (Schecter).

sp.speaker: Albert

lg.l: Still 'tis louder! And I remember the Portugals
Informed us they had often heard such sounds
But ne'er could touch the shore from whence whence: where it came.
Follow me, my Aminta! My good genius,
Show me the way still! Horns again.
Still we are directed!
When we gain the top of this near rising hill
We shall know further.

sp.stage:
Exit Albert and Aminta
and enter above.

lg.l: Courteous Zephyrus Zephyrus: Greek god of the west wind
On his dewy wings carries perfumes to cheer us—
The air clears too—
And now we may discern discern: perceive, recognize another island
And, questionless, the seat of fortunate men.
Oh that we could arrive there!
No, Albert, 'tis not to be hoped.
This envious torrent's cruelly interposed interposed: placed between.
We have no vessel that may transport us
Nor hath nature given us wings to fly.
Better try all hazards hazards: risks of loss or harm, dangers
Than perish here remediless! I feel
New vigor in me, and a spirit that dares
More than a man to serve my fair Aminta.
These arms shall be my oars with which I'll swim,
And my zeal to save thy innocent self
Like wings shall bear me up above the brackish waves.
Will ye then leave me?
'Til now I ne'er was wretched.
My best Aminta, I swear by goodness
'Tis nor hope, nor fear of myself, that invites me
To this extreme; 'tis to supply thy wants wants: shortages. And believe me,
Though pleasure met me in most ravishing ravishing: characterized by exciting pleasure or ecstasy forms
And happiness courted me to entertain her,
I would nor eat nor sleep 'til I returned
And crowned thee with my fortunes.
Oh but your absence—!
Suppose it but a dream and, as you may,
Endeavor to take rest; and when that sleep
Deceives your hunger with imagined food,
Think you have sent me for discovery
Of some most fortunate continent yet unknown
Which you are to be queen of.
And now, ye powers that e'er heard lovers' prayers
Or cherished pure affection, look on him
That is your votary votary: one bound or devoted to worship or a particular vow and make it known,
Against all stops, you can defend your own.
How did we lose Clarinda?
When we believed the stag was spent spent: used up, worn out and would take soil,
The sight of the black lake, which we supposed
He chose for his last refuge, frighted him more
Than we that did pursue him.
That's usual, for death itself is not so terrible
To any beast of chase beast of chase: i.e. animal being hunted.
Since we lived here, we ne'er could force one to it.
'Tis so dreadful
Birds, that with their pinions cleave the air,
Dare not fly over it. When the stag turned head
And we even tired with labor, Clarinda, as if
She were made of air and fire
And had no part of earth in her, eagerly pursued him.
Nor need we fear her safety; this place yields not
Fawns and satyrs or more lustful lustful: desirous of sexual satisfaction men.
Here we live secure,
And have among ourselves a commonwealth commonwealth: political body in which every member has a voice or vested interest

Which, in ourselves begun, with us must end. with us must end: As the commonwealth's rules forbid any contact with men (thus ruling out any forms of reproduction), these same rules will lead to the ultimate demise of the women and, with them, the commonwealth itself.
Ay, there's the misery.
But, being alone,
Allow me freedom but to speak my thoughts:
The strictness of our governess that forbids us
On pain of death the sight and use of men
Is more than tyranny. For herself, she's past
Those youthful heats and feels not the want want: lack
Of that which young maids long for. And her daughter,
The fair Clarinda, though in years
Improved in height and large proportion,
Came here so young
That, scarce remembering that she had a father,
She never dreams of man, and should she see one
In my opinion a'would i.e.: he would appear a strange beast to her.
'Tis not so with us.
For my part I confess it: I was not made
For this single life, nor do I love hunting so
But that I had rather be the chase myself.
By Venus Venus: Roman goddess of beauty and love (out upon me, I should have sworn
By Diana Diana: Roman goddess of hunting and virginity ), I am of thy mind too, wench!
And though I have ta'en an oath not alone
To detest but never to think of man,
Every hour something tells me I am forsworn,
For I confess imagination helps me sometimes
And that's all is left for us to feed on;
We might starve, else. For if I have any pleasure
In this life, but when I sleep I am a pagan pagan: non-Christian, thought also at this time to be uncivilized;
Then from the courtier to the country clown,
I have strange visions visions: i.e. in dreams.
Visions, Crocale?
Yes, and fine visions, too,
And visions I hope in dreams are harmless

And not forbid by our canons canons: rules, laws, or decrees, usually ecclesiastical. This word choice goes hand-in-hand with the ongoing theme of faith and religion throughout this play. Disobeying the canons not only breaks the commonwealth law but is also figured here as a type of sin.. The last night
(Truth, 'tis a foolish one, but I must tell it)
As I lay in my cabin betwixt sleeping and waking—
Upon your back?
How should a young maid lie, fool,
When she would be entranced?
We are instructed. Forward, I prithee.
Methought a sweet young man—
In years some twenty, with a downy chin
Promising a future beard, and yet no red one—
Stole slyly to my cabin all unbraced,
Took me in his arms, and kissed me twenty times!
Yet still I slept—
Fie Fie: exclamation inciting shame, usually said to children! Thy lips run over, Crocale!
But to the rest—
Lord, what a man is this, thought I,
To do this to a maid!
Yet then, for my life I could not wake.
The youth, a little daunted, with a trembling hand
Heaved up the clothes—
Yet still you slept—
I'faith I did! And when methoughts he was warm by my side,
Thinking to catch him, I stretched out both mine arms,
And when I felt him not, I shrieked out
And waked for anger!
'Twas a pretty dream.
Ay, if it had been a true one!
But stay stay: wait, what's here cast o'th' shore?
'Tis a man!
Shall I shoot him?
No, no, 'tis a handsome beast!
Would we had more o'the breed. Stand close, wenches,
And let's hear if he can speak.
Do I yet live?
Sure it is air I breath. What place is this?
Sure something more than human more than human: i.e. divine or supernatural keeps residence here,
For I have passed the Stygian Stygian: from Greek mythology, referring to the river Styx which divided Earth from the underworld gulph
And touch upon the blessed shore! 'Tis so:
This is the Elysian Elysian: from Greek mythology, referring to Elysium, the heavenly paradise for fallen Greek heroes shade. These happy spirits
That here enjoy all pleasures—
He makes toward us He makes toward us: i.e. He approaches us.
Stand, or I'll shoot!
Hold, he makes no resistance.
Be not offended, goddesses, that I fall
Thus prostrate at your feet; or if not such if not such: i.e. if you are not goddesses,

But nymphs of Dian's Dian: i.e. Diana, Roman goddess of hunting and virginity train Nymphs of Dian's train: The combined effect of the references to Elysium, Styx, and Diana show a shift from Albert's presumably French Catholic faith to a classical mythological frame of mind. that range these groves
Which you forbid to men, vouchsafe vouchsafe: acknowledge or bestow in some favorable manner to know
I am a man, a wicked sinful man, and yet not sold
So far to impudence as to presume
To press upon your privacies press upon your privacies: i.e. intrude upon, importune or provoke
Your heavenly angers. 'Tis not for myself
I beg thus poorly, for I am already wounded,
Wounded to death, and faint. My last breath
Is for a virgin comes as near yourselves
In all perfection comes as ... perfection: i.e. Aminta's beauty approaches that of the commonwealth women as what's mortal may
Resemble things divine. Oh pity her
And let your charity free her from that desert
If heavenly charity can reach to hell—
For sure that place comes near it—and where'er
My ghost shall find abode,
Eternally I shall pour blessings on ye.
By my life I can not hurt him.
Though I lose my head for it, nor I.
I must pity him, and will.
But stay stay: stop! Clarinda —
What new game game: hunted animal have ye found here? Ha!
What beast is this lies wallowing in his gore?
Keep off—
Wherefore, I pray? I ne'er turned
From a fell fell: intensely destructive, dreadful lioness robbed of her whelps whelps: in this case, lion cubs,
And shall I fear dead carrion carrion: dead body, putrefying flesh?
O but—
But what is't?
It is infectious.
Has it not a name?
Yes, but such a name from which
As from the devil your mother commands us fly. Yes, but ... us fly: Crocale is referring to the command from Rosella that all commonwealth women refuse men's company.
Is it a man?
It is.
What a brave brave: fine, worthy shape it has in death.
How excellent would it appear had it life!
Why should it be infectious? I have heard
My mother say I had a father;
And was not he a man?
Questionless, madam.
Your fathers, too, were men?
Without doubt, lady.
And without such, it is impossible
We could have been.
A sin against nature to deny it.
Nor can you or I have any hope to be a mother
Without the help of men.
Impossible.
Which of you, then, most barbarous that knew
You from a man had being and owe to it
The name of parent, durst durst: archaic past tense of dare presume to kill
The likeness of that thing by which you are?
Whose arrows made these wounds? Speak, or by Dian Dian: i.e. Diana, Roman goddess of hunting and virginity
Without distinction, I'll let fly let fly: shoot arrows at ye all!
Not mine.
Nor mine.
('Tis strange to see her moved thus.)
Restrain your fury, madam! Had we killed him
We had but performed your mother's command.
But if she command unjust and cruel things,
We are not to obey it.
We are innocent. Some storm did cast
Him shipwrecked on the shore as you see, wounded,
Nor durst durst: archaic past tense of dare we be surgeons to such
Your mother doth appoint for death.
Weak excuse; where's pity?
Where's soft compassion? Cruel and ungrateful!
Did providence providence: divine guidance offer to your charity
But one poor subject to express it on—
And in't to show our wants wants: shortages too—and could you
So carelessly neglect it?
For aught aught: all I know, he's living yet,
And you may tempt your mother by giving him succor succor: help, aid, or assistance.
Ha! Come near, I charge charge: order ye.
So, bend his body softly, rub his temples—
Nay, that shall be my office office: duty or service. How the red
Steals into his pale lips! Run and fetch the simples simples: medicines containing a single active ingredient, derived directly from nature without human manipulation
With which my mother held my arm
When last I was wounded by the boar.
Do, but remember her remember her: i.e. remind or request her to come after ye
That she may behold her daughter's charity.
Now he breathes—

The air passing through the Arabian groves Arabian groves: Though the phrase "Arabian groves" is vague, it could suggest the increased cross-pollination of horticulture between Europe and the Middle East and India. Portugal had colonized several territories (Bahrain, Sohar, Julfar, Quriyat), now constituting modern-day Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, during the reign of the Iberian Union between 1580-1640 (de Oliveira Marques, 322). The Amazons are also believed to have originated in Libya and to have migrated across Syria, Egypt, Scythia (Foreman). The Arabian groves reference could refer to the coconut and palm trees that were commonly seen on the coast of Southwest India. After the conquests of Vasco Da Gama, Portugal colonized territories like Bombay and Goa by the Arabian Sea before India's major colonization by the British in the late seventeenth century (Narayanan, 198). It is therefore possible for Indian horticultural features to appear in an imagined Portuguese aesthetic.
Yields not so sweet an odor! Prithee, taste it,
Taste it, good Crocale, yet I envy thee so great a blessing.
'Tis not sin to touch these rubies, is it?
Not, I think—

Or thus to live chameleon-like chameleon-like: Perhaps a reference to the chameleon's ability to blend into its surroundings, i.e. Clarinda will need to render her desire for Albert invisible because of the commonwealth's law against interacting with men. More likely, though, this refers to the belief that chameleons survived solely on air since Clarinda has been referring to Albert's breath. See William Shakespeare's The Two Gentlemen of Verona, where chameleons are referenced as both air-eaters and color-changers.
I could resign my essence to live ever thus.
Oh welcome! Raise him up gently. Some soft hand
Bound up these wounds; a woman's hair. What fury
For which my ignorance does not know a name
Is crept into my bosom? But I forget Enter Hippolita with medicine.
My pious pious: pitiful, devoted, faithful work. Now, if this juice juice: i.e. the medicine referenced earlier hath power,
Let it appear. His eyelids ope': prodigious prodigious: astonishing, amazing!
Two suns break break: burst forth from these orbs!
Ha! Where am I? What new vision's this?
To what goddess do I owe this second life?
Sure thou art more than mortal,
And any sacrifice of thanks or duty
In poor and wretched man to pay comes short
Of your immortal bounty bounty: generosity. But to show
I am not unthankful, thus in humility
I kiss the happy ground you have made sacred
By bearing of your weight.
No goddess, friend, but made
Of that same brittle mold as you are,
One too acquainted with calamities
And, from that, apt to pity. Charity ever
Finds in the act reward, and needs not trumpet
In the receiver. Charity ever ... receiver: i.e. Kind acts are their own reward and do not require praise Oh, forbear forbear: abstain from this duty!
I have a hand to meet with yours
And lips to bid yours welcome.
I see that, by instinct,
Though a young maid hath never seen a man,
Touches have titillations and inform her Though ... inform her: i.e. Though Clarinda has never met a man, instinctually she knows about sexual attraction.. Enter Rosella.
But here's our governess;
Now I expect a storm.
Child of my flesh
And not of my fair unspotted unspotted: unblemished mind,
Unhand this monster!
Monster, mother?
Yes, and every word he speaks, a siren's note

To drown the careless hearer siren's note ... hearer: Rosella likens Albert to the figure of the siren to reinforce her argument that men are dangerously manipulative. Based in Greek mythology, "sirens" were creatures that were part-women, part-bird or mermaid. They would lure sailors to destruction by enchanting them with song. Sirens have been traditionally gendered as women, but Rosella inverts this association, emphasizing Albert's manipulation. This linguistic inversion points to the larger theme of reversing traditional gender roles within play.. Have I not taught thee
The falsehood and the perjuries of men
On whom but for a woman to show pity
Is to be cruel to herself? The sovereignty sovereignty: supreme power or domination
Proud and imperious imperious: domineering men usurp usurp: inflict wrongfully upon us
We confer confer: grant or agree to on ourselves, and love those fetters fetters: binds, chains
We fasten to our freedoms. Have we, Clarinda,
Since thy father's wreck, sought liberty
To lose it uncompelled uncompelled: without force? Did Fortune guide—
Or rather, destiny—our bark bark: wooden ship, to which
We could appoint no port appoint no port: find no safe harbor, to this blessed place
Inhabited heretofore heretofore: before now by warlike women
That kept men in subjection? Did we then,
By their example, after we had lost
All we could love in man, here plant ourselves
With execrable execrable: awful, cursed oaths never to look
On man but as a monster? And wilt thou
Be the first precedent precedent: instance establishing rule or guide to infringe infringe: breach, violate those vows
We made to heaven?
Hear me, and hear with justice,
And as ye are delighted in the name
Of mother, hear a daughter that would be like you:
Should all women use use: in this case, maintain, adhere to this obstinate abstinence
You would force upon us, in a few years
The whole world would be peopled
Only with beasts.
We must and will have men.
Ay, or we'll shake off all obedience.
Are ye mad?
Can no persuasion alter ye? Suppose
You had my suffrage suffrage: support, often in a spiritual or ecclesiastical sense to your suit suit: legal petition; entreaty:
Can this shipwrecked wretch supply them all? Can this ... all?: i.e. Can this single man provide all the commonwealth women with children
Hear me, great lady!
I have fellows in my misery not far hence.
Divided Divided: Separated [from us] only by this hellish river,
There live a company of wretched men
Such as your charity may make your slaves.
Imagine all the miseries mankind
May suffer under, and they groan beneath 'em.
But are they like to you?
Speak they your language?
Are they able, lusty lusty: vigorous men?
They were, good ladies,
And in their May of youth, of gentle blood of gentle blood: born into nobility; also, of gentle manners
And such as may deserve ye. Now cold and hunger
Hath lessened their perfection, but restored
To what they were, I doubt not they'll appear
Worthy of your favors.
This is a blessing
We durst durst: archaic past tense of dare not hope for.
Dear mother, be not obdurate obdurate: resistant to influence, physically hard.
Hear then my resolution, and labor not
To add to what I'll grant grant: consent to, for 'twill be fruitless:
You shall appear as good angels to these wretched men.
In a small boat we'll pass o'er to 'em
And bring 'em comfort. If you like their persons,
And they approve of yours—for we'll force nothing—
And since we want want: lack ceremonies ceremonies: religious engagements ,
Each one shall choose a husband and enjoy
His company a month, but that expired
You shall no more come near 'em. If you prove fruitful If you prove fruitful: i.e. If you become pregnant,
The males ye shall return to them, the females

We will reserve ourselves The males ... reserve ourselves: Rosella's command is that any boys born by the commonwealth women will be given to the men, while any girls will stay with the women and become part of the commonwealth. The historical Amazons were supposedly neighbors to an all-male society called the Gargareans. They met annually for a mating ritual. The female children born after this ritual were retained by the Amazons, and the male children went to their fathers (Strabo). Rosella's reference to this practice of mating with an all-male society had historical precedent. It also provides some geographical hints. As the Gargareans and Amazons are believed to have reigned between Eurasia and the Middle East, the play hints at taking place in the Mediterranean or Black Sea. (Indeed, the play references a black river between the barren and fertile islands.). This is the utmost
Ye shall e'er obtain. As ye think fit,
Ye may dismiss this stranger
And prepare tomorrow for the journey.
Come, sir, will ye walk?
We will show ye our pleasant bowers bowers: natural dwellings, habitations, or abodes typically used for amorous meetings
And something ye shall find to cheer your heart.
Excellent lady,
Though 'twill appear a wonder one near starved
Should refuse rest and meat, I must not take
Your noble noble: fine, splendid offer. I left in yonder desert
A virgin almost pined pined: starved or wasted—
She's not your wife?
No, lady, but my sister ('tis now dangerous
To speak truth). To her I deeply vowed
Not to taste food or rest if Fortune brought it me,
'Til I blessed her with my return. Now, if you please
To afford afford: allow, provide me an easy passage to her
And some meat for her recovery,
I shall live your slave, and thankfully
She shall ever acknowledge her life at your service.
You plead so well I can deny ye nothing.
I myself will see you furnished furnished: provided,
And with the next sun visit and relieve thee.

Ye are all goodness— Ye are all goodness—: The long dash closing this act (present in the 1647 folio text) adds a level of ambiguity to the exit. Other instances of long dashes in the 1647 folio are used to indicate interruptions in the dialogue. Therefore, we could assume that Albert is being interrupted at the closing of the scene, though the text does not give indication of exactly what or who could be interrupting Albert. The long dash could allow actors to vary the portrayal of this end scene. One implication could be that Albert and Clarinda walk out of the stage with redundant pleasantries, formalities, and exchanges that the authors and printers did not deem worthy of consuming the page's highly sought-for space. Another implication could be that the next scene immediately follows as they exit. The dash could also represent space on the page, indicating that more words were spoken here, up to the actors' or the company's discretion or improvisation.

listBibl.bibl: Adams, Carol J. The Sexual Politics of Meat. (Bloomsbury Publishing, 2015).
Banerjee, Rita. "Gold, Land, and Labor: Ideologies of Colonization and Rewriting 'The Tempest' in 1622." Studies in Philology, vol. 110, no. 2 (2013): pp. 291–317.

Bourne, Claire M. L., ed. Fletcher, John, and Philip Massinger, 'A Wife for a Month,' in. The Routledge Anthology of Early Modern Drama, gen ed. edited by Claire M. L. Bourne and Jeremy Lopez, (Routledge, 2020).
de Oliveira Marques, António, Henrique R. History of Portugal (Columbia University Press, 1972).
Dessen, Alan C., and Leslie Thomson. A Dictionary of Stage Directions in English Drama, 1580-1642. (Cambridge University Press, 1999).

Foreman, Amanda. "The Amazon Women: Is there any truth behind the myth." Smithsonian Magazine (April 2014). Available online: https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/amazon-women-there-any-truth-behind-myth-180950188/.
Habakkuk, H. J. "Marriage Settlements in the Eighteenth Century." Transactions of the Royal Historical Society 32 (1950): 15–30.

Jackson, MacDonald P. “The Revenger’s Tragedy (1607) in Taylor, Gary, and John Lavagnino. Thomas Middleton and Early Modern Textual Culture: A Companion to The Collected Works, eds Taylor, Gary, and John Lavagnino. (Oxford, 2007), 548-61.
Jowitt, Claire. "'Her flesh must serve you': Gender, Commerce and the New World in Fletcher's and Massinger's A Wife for a Month and Massinger's The City Madam." Parergon 18.3 (2001): p. 93-117.
Lublin, Robert I. Costuming the Shakespearean Stage: Visual Codes of Representation in Early Modern Theatre and Culture. PhD dissertation. The Ohio State University, 2003.
McInnis, David. Mind-Travelling and Voyage Drama in Early Modern England. (Palgrave Macmillan, 2013).

Moore, Gaywyn Patricia, and Andrea Bernadette. "English Women, Romance, and Global Travel in Thomas Heywood's The Fair Maid of the West, Part 1," in Travel and Travail: Early Modern Women, English Drama, and the Wider World, edited by Patricia Akhimie and Andrea Bernadette (University of Nebraska Press, 2019), p. 313-30.
Narayanan, M. G. S. Calicut: The City of Truth. (Calicut University Publications, 2006).
O'Brien, Jane. "Shakespeare's Evolving Attitudes towards Women." BBC News, 27 April, 2015. Available online: www.bbc.com/news/magazine-32379759.
Schecter, John M. "Adufe." Grove Music Online. Available online: https://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/grovemusic/view/10.1093/gmo/9781561592630.001.0001/omo-9781561592630-e-4002232233.
Squadrilli, Luciana. "What Is Bottarga?" Great Italian Chefs, 23 Nov. 2019. Available on line: https://www.greatitalianchefs.com/features/what-is-bottarga.
Strabo. Geography. Book 11, Chapter 5, Section 1 (Loeb Classical Library, 1928). Available online: http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Strabo/11E*.html.
Sugg, Richard. "Medicinal Cannibalism in Early Modern Literature and Culture." Literature Compass 10.11 (2013): 825-835.
Syme, Holger Schott. Theatre and Testimony in Shakespeare's England: A Culture of Mediation. (Cambridge University Press, 2014).
Syme, Holger Schott. "The Theatre of Shakespeare's Time." The Norton Shakespeare, 3rd ed., edited by Stephen Greenblatt, et al (W. W. Norton, 2015), 93-118.
Thomson, Leslie. "The Meaning of 'Thunder and Lightning': Stage Directions and Audience Expectations." Early Theatre 2 (1999): 11-24.
Williams, Gordon. A Dictionary of Sexual Language and Imagery in Shakespearean and Stuart Literature. (The Athlone Press, 1994).

interpGrp.interp: Words or phrases related to food/drink or eating/drinking.
Words or phrases that refer to objects present on stage.
Words or phrases related to places, including specific geographic locations, that characters are, have been, or imagine going.
Words or phrases related to religion or spiritual practices.
Words or phrases that are names or represent people.
